Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Gaining a molecular level understanding of the sorption of model organic molecules to engineered soil surrogates
Award.AbstractNarration:
The funding of this project by the Environmental Chemical Sciences program in the Division of Chemistry will enable Professors Robert Cook and David Spivak of Louisiana State University (LSU) and Karl Mueller of Pennsylvania State University (PSU) to introduce a postdoctoral fellow, graduate students, and undergraduate students to interdisciplinary research involving organic, analytical, and environmental chemistry. Recruitment will focus on students from underrepresented groups who will be introduced to the complexity of environmental chemical issues. In his graduate-level polymer synthesis class, Professor Spivak will show how emerging methods of polymer synthesis can be used to mimic some of nature's complexity and can aid environmental chemistry. Professors Cook (LSU) and Mueller (PSU), both of whom teach senior-level environmental chemistry courses, will incorporate findings and approaches developed in this award to illustrate how fundamental chemical interactions apply to environmental systems and how they play a role in the determination of the fate and transport of anthropogenic chemicals in the environment.

This project is aimed at a molecular level understanding of how pesticides interact with soils by studying the uptake of model pesticide molecules by engineered soil surrogates (ESS). Surrogates will be synthesized by functionalizing known mineral surfaces with organic moieties of varying composition and polarity, echoing those found in real soil. Similarly, incorporating fluorinated pesticides of varied polarities and chemical compositions, in concert with a range of NMR methods, will enable molecular level characterization of the interactions. The NMR experiments will be guided and complemented by batch sorption studies, which will report the corresponding macroscopic behavior. Broader impacts of this work include improvement of fate and transport modeling, better practices for pesticide use and design, and an increased understanding of non-covalent interactions. These detailed studies will provide molecular level insights into how pollutants interact and associate with soils.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at developing a molecular level understanding of how organic molecules (and especially those that act as pesticides) interact with soils by studying the uptake of model molecules by engineered soil surrogates (ESSs). These ESSs were synthesized by collaborators at Louisiana State University (LSU) through functionalization of model mineral surfaces (silicas, clays) with organic moieties of varying composition and polarity that echo those found in real soil. The incorporation of fluorinated pesticides of varied polarities and chemical composition, in concert with a range of nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) methods, enabled molecular level characterization of the interactions between the ESS matrix and the pesticide probe molecules.

 

The intellectual merit of this work stemmed from the ability to clearly identify the interaction between organic molecules and ESSs.  Real soil is an extremely complex and heterogeneous mixture of inorganic and organic materials, and so identifying the nature of the interaction between molecules (such as pesticides) and soil is a complex problem. Nevertheless, to best understand how to control and mitigate or remediate pesticide runoff, it is crucial to understand these interactions.  Such understanding will aid in guiding the design of new pesticides to reduce unwanted contamination, as well as the usage of already existing pesticides. This work aimed at developing analytical techniques and approaches that would enable the identification of these interactions.

 

The work has had several broader impacts. First, the grant supported the training of graduate students, who will form the future scientific workforce of the United States. Second, the work aims to aid our understanding of the interaction of organic molecules (such as pesticides and fertilizers) with soil.  At present, there is a large need to help mitigate or remediate the run-off of such compounds.  This work addresses these needs.  Finally, the graduate students supported on this project have participated in outreach activities at Penn State, such as Upward Bound.  This is a program that brings high school students from at-risk schools throughout Pennsylvania to Penn State for a summer school.  As part of this program, the graduate students supported on this project have helped these students perform experiments within my laboratory.  The goal of this program is to show the high school students modern research and inspire them to attend college in the future. As an added benefit, the graduate students that participate learn managerial and project planning skills. Again, this will benefit them (and society) in their futures roles as leaders in science.
